column3:
The test that failed on Travis produced the following stacktrace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/build/bitcoin/bitcoin/build/bitcoin-i686-pc-linux-gnu/test/functional/segwit.py", line 673, in <module>
    SegWitTest().main()
  File "/home/travis/build/bitcoin/bitcoin/build/bitcoin-i686-pc-linux-gnu/test/functional/test_framework/test_framework.py", line 142,
I restarted your travis test. Segwit.py failure is probably due to the return code bug fixed in #11831

Thanks @ryanofsky. For future reference, is there a way I can restart the test on Travis myself? (Short of pushing a change, I mean.)\n\nI've taken a stab at updating doc/release-notes.md as well in this PR. Let me know how that looks.
I think if you're a github project member you can restart travis jobs.

Ah, you mean if you authorize travis-ci.org to access your Github repos / orgs some button shows up on the build results page? I've been avoiding that due to the wide-ranging permissions they ask for, but maybe there's a need to be pragmatic..

> Ah, you mean if you authorize travis-ci.org to access your Github repos / orgs some button shows up on the build results page? I've been avoiding that due to the wide-ranging permissions they ask for, but maybe there's a need to be pragmatic..\n\nIf you become a member of the bitcoin/bitcoin github project, a "restart job" button shows up letting you restart travis runs associated with bitcoin

Thanks for explaining Travis stuff, @ryanofsky, makes sense. I'm not going to bother poking anyone around joining the bitcoin project on GH at this time, I think, but will wait until I've made some more sizeable contributions.\n\nSince tests passed on CI I think this can be merged at any time you want. (I'm still trying to debug the test failures I mentioned above, some of which seem persistent,
cc @TheBlueMatt @achow101, this PR is the follow-up we discussed in #11830, in case you would like to review and/or merge.
